thread.title: Washington Fish and Wildlife bans campfires, target shooting due to wildfire risk | News | kxly.com
thread.title_full: Washington Fish and Wildlife bans campfires, target shooting due to wildfire risk | News | kxly.com

author: Rob King
title: Washington Fish and Wildlife bans campfires, target shooting due to wildfire risk | News | kxly.com
text: SPOKANE, WA -- The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife is restricting what people can do on state lands in Eastern Washington to help reduce wildfire risk. WDFW says starting July 1, the following changes go into effect on state lands: SPOKANE, WA -- The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife is restricting what people can do on state lands in Eastern Washington to help reduce wildfire risk. WDFW says starting July 1, the following changes go into effect on state lands: - All campfires including those in fire rings are prohibited. Personal gas camp stoves will still be allowed. - Shooting firearms when not lawfully hunting. Target shooting can only be done at two department shooting ranges, Methow Shooting Range and Asotin Creek Shooting Range until August 15. - From August 16-September 15, all target shooting including at the ranges is prohibited. - Smoking is prohibited expect in an enclosed vehicle. - Welding and operating chainsaws is prohibited. - Operating a motor vehicle away from developed roads is prohibited. For more information, check the [Washington Wildfire Information Page](https://wdfw.wa.gov/about/wdfw-lands/wildfire). “We all have a part to play in preventing wildfires, and we’re urging visitors enjoying Washington’s great outdoors this summer to be a part of the solution,” said Cynthia Wilkerson, WDFW’s Lands Division Manager. “By recreating responsibly and following wildfire safety restrictions, visitors can help protect public recreation lands, wildlife habitat, and health and safety for local communities.” COPYRIGHT 2024 BY KXLY.
